content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

In this game, if we both consistently choose the same option (R or B), our earnings would be different each round, but our total earnings over 75 rounds might end up being the same due to the payoff differences.

However, considering that the player is anonymous and I don't know their strategy, the best strategy for me as a human player in this situation would be to choose an option that maximizes my average payoff per round while also taking into account that my opponent might adapt their strategy over time.

One possible strategy could be to use mixed strategies, meaning that I don't always pick R or B consistently but rather a combination of both. This approach can potentially confuse the other player and make it harder for them to predict my choice, thus increasing my chances of earning more than if I were to stick with one option only.

In practice, this could look like picking R around 50% of the time (e.g., R{R} or B{R}) and B around 50% of the time (e.g., R{B} or B{B}). However, since I am an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment, it is possible that the game might have specific rules or restrictions that could influence my strategy decision.

In summary, I would choose R{R, B}, indicating that I will make a random choice between R and B for each round of the game.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since both of us picked B in the previous round, we will each earn 40$ for that round. Now, let's move on to the next round.
